A report by [[Ben Emmerson|Ben Emmerson QC]], the UN's special rapporteur on human rights and counter-terrorism, who identified 33 drone strikes around the world that have resulted in civilian casualties and may have violated international humanitarian law urged the United States "to further clarify its position on the legal and factual issues ... to declassify, to the maximum extent possible, information relevant to its lethal extraterritorial counter-terrorism operations; and to release its own data on the level of civilian casualties inflicted through the use of remotely piloted aircraft, together with information on the evaluation methodology used".<ref>{{cite news|last=Bowcott|first=Owen|title=Drone strikes by US may violate international law, says UN|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/drone-strikes-us-violate-law-un|accessdate=18 October 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131018144447/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/drone-strikes-us-violate-law-un|archive-date=18 October 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] said that in Yemen more civilians were killed than admitted by the Obama administration, while Amnesty International said the same of drone strikes in Pakistan. Caitlin Hayden, a White House spokeswoman, declined to comment on the reports, but said in an e-mail statement: "As the President emphasized, the use of lethal force, including from remotely piloted aircraft, commands the highest level of attention and care."<ref>{{cite news|last=Whitlock|first=Craig|title=Drone strikes killing more civilians than U.S. admits, human rights groups say|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/drone-strikes-killing-more-civilians-than-us-admits-human-rights-groups-say/2013/10/21/a99cbe78-3a81-11e3-b7ba-503fb5822c3e_story.html|accessdate=22 October 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=22 October 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022080807/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/drone-strikes-killing-more-civilians-than-us-admits-human-rights-groups-say/2013/10/21/a99cbe78-3a81-11e3-b7ba-503fb5822c3e_story.html|archive-date=22 October 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
While the U.S. government is considering whether to kill an American abroad suspected of planning terrorist attacks and how to do so legally under new stricter targeting policy issued in 2013,<ref name="AP20140210">{{cite news|title=Obama officials weigh drone attack on US suspect|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/us-suspect-possibly-targeted-drone-attack|accessdate=13 February 2014|agency=Associated Press|date=10 February 2014|author1=Kimberly Dozier|author2=Nedra Pickler|lastauthoramp=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222221736/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/us-suspect-possibly-targeted-drone-attack|archive-date=22 February 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=White House Fact Sheet on: U.S. Policy Standards and Procedures for the Use of Force in Counterterrorism Operations Outside the United States and Areas of Active Hostilities|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/uploads/2013.05.23_fact_sheet_on_ppg.pdf|work=The White House|publisher=The White House|accessdate=13 February 2014|date=23 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203214706/http://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/default/files/uploads/2013.05.23_fact_sheet_on_ppg.pdf|archivedate=3 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[The Intercept]] reported that the U.S. government is using primarily NSA surveillance to target people for drone strikes overseas. In its report ''The Intercept'' the author details the flawed methods which are used to locate targets for lethal drone strikes, resulting in the deaths of innocent people.<ref>{{cite news|title=The NSA's Secret Role in the U.S. Assassination Program|url=https://firstlook.org/theintercept/article/2014/02/10/the-nsas-secret-role/|accessdate=13 February 2014|newspaper=The Intercept|date=10 February 2014|author1=Jeremy Scahill|author2=Glenn Greenwald|lastauthoramp=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210072132/https://firstlook.org/theintercept/article/2014/02/10/the-nsas-secret-role/|archive-date=10 February 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the ''Washington Post'', NSA analysts and collectors (i.e. NSA personnel who control electronic surveillance equipment) use the NSA's sophisticated surveillance capabilities to track individual targets geographically and in real time, while drones and tactical units aim their weaponry against those targets to take them out.<ref>{{cite news|last=Priest|first=Dana|title=NSA growth fueled by need to target terrorists|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-growth-fueled-by-need-to-target-terrorists/2013/07/21/24c93cf4-f0b1-11e2-bed3-b9b6fe264871_story.html|accessdate=14 February 2014|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=22 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140216143545/http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/nsa-growth-fueled-by-need-to-target-terrorists/2013/07/21/24c93cf4-f0b1-11e2-bed3-b9b6fe264871_story.html|archive-date=16 February 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
NBC News released in February 2014 an undated Department of Justice White paper entitled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qa'ida or An Associated Force" in which the Obama Administration concludes that the U.S. government can order the killing of American citizens if they are believed to be "senior operational leaders" of al-Qaida or "an associated force" – even if there is no intelligence indicating they are engaged in an active plot to attack the U.S.<ref name="NBCIsikoff20140204">{{cite news|last1=Isikoff|first1=Michael|title=Justice Department memo reveals legal case for drone strikes on Americans|accessdate=15 August 2014|publisher=NBC News|date=4 February 2013|url=http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/04/16843014-justice-department-memo-reveals-legal-case-for-drone-strikes-on-americans?lite|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819060747/http://investigations.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/04/16843014-justice-department-memo-reveals-legal-case-for-drone-strikes-on-americans?lite|archive-date=19 August 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="DOJMemoLawfulnessLethalOperatation">{{cite news|title=Undated memo entitled "Lawfulness of a Lethal Operation Directed Against a U.S. Citizen who is a Senior Operational Leader of Al Qa'ida or An Associated Force" by the U.S. Department of Justice|url=http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/msnbc/sections/news/020413_DOJ_White_Paper.pdf|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=15 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826075931/http://msnbcmedia.msn.com/i/msnbc/sections/news/020413_DOJ_White_Paper.pdf|archive-date=26 August 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However any such targeted killing operation by the United States would have to comply with the four fundamental law-of-war principles governing the use of force which are necessity, distinction, proportionality and humanity – i.e., the avoidance of unnecessary suffering. (Page 8 of <ref name="DOJMemoLawfulnessLethalOperatation" />). The memo also discusses why targeted killings would not be a war crime or violate [[Executive Order 12333|a U.S. executive order banning assassinations]]:
"A lawful killing in self-defense is not an assassination. In the Department's view, a lethal operation conducted against a U.S. citizen whose conduct poses an imminent threat of violent attack against the United States would be a legitimate act of national self-defense that would not violate the assassination ban. Similarly, the use of lethal force, consistent with the laws of war, against an individual who is a legitimate military target would be lawful and would not violate the assassination ban."<ref name="NBCIsikoff20140204" />
In 2013, a report on drone warfare and aerial sovereignty proposed that U.S. government drone policy in Pakistan potentially violated human rights according to the U.N. [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]]. The rights in direct question were the right to life; right to a fair trial; the freedom of association; right to protection of the family; and, less directly, right to highest attainable health standards; right to education; and right of freedom from hunger.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Drones and the Chicago Convention: An Examination of the Concepts of Aerial Sovereignty, The War on Terror and the Notion of Self Defense in Relation to the Chicago Convention |publisher=University of Pretoria |year=2013 |last=Bradley |first=Martha }}</ref>
On 21 April 2014, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit overturned the above-mentioned December 2012 ruling by U.S. District Judge [[Colleen McMahon]] and ruled that the Obama administration must release documents justifying its drone-killings of Americans and foreigners.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wolfgang|first1=Ben|title=Court rules Obama administration must justify targeted killings|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/apr/21/court-rules-obama-administration-must-justify-targ/|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=The Washington Post|date=21 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813214607/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/apr/21/court-rules-obama-administration-must-justify-targ/|archive-date=13 August 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal released on 23 June 2014 a Juli 2010 memo by then U.S. Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel David Barron which outlined the rationale for killing the American Citizen [[Anwar al-Aulaqi]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Savage|first1=Charlie|title=Justice Department Memo Approving Targeted Killing of Anwar Al-Awlaki|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/06/23/us/23awlaki-memo.html|accessdate=15 August 2014|work=The New York Times|date=23 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819092958/http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/06/23/us/23awlaki-memo.html|archive-date=19 August 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sledge|first1=Matt|title=Drone Memo Justifying Anwar al-Awlaki's Killing Released|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/23/anwar-al-awlaki-drone-memo_n_5522067.html|accessdate=15 August 2014|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=23 June 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819092006/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/23/anwar-al-awlaki-drone-memo_n_5522067.html|archive-date=19 August 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
CIA-ordered drone strikes were eventually ended by President Obama, who transferred control entirely to the U.S. military, under a separate legal authority. President Trump reversed this decision in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/03/14/520162910/trump-restores-cia-power-to-launch-drone-strikes |title=Trump Restores CIA Power To Launch Drone Strikes |access-date=31 May 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180922135945/https://www.npr.org/2017/03/14/520162910/trump-restores-cia-power-to-launch-drone-strikes |archive-date=22 September 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Asia == === Use by Iranian government === {{main|List of Iranian assassinations|Chain murders of Iran}} Alleged and confirmed assassinations were reported to have been conducted by the [[Islamic Republic of Iran]] and previously by the [[Pahlavi regime]]. It includes attempts on notable persons who were reported to have been specifically targeted by the various Iranian [[Armed Forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran|security]] and [[Ministry of Intelligence and National Security (Iran)|intelligence]] forces, most notably against [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] dissidents of the [[Kurdish Democratic Party of Iran]] in the 1980s and 1990s.<ref>{{cite news|title=German court implicates Iran leaders in '92 killings|url=http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9704/10/germany.iran/|work=CNN|date=10 April 1997|access-date=4 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126101651/http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/9704/10/germany.iran/|archive-date=26 November 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Prior to the establishment of the Islamic State in 1979, the [[SAVAK|Organization of Intelligence and National Security]] also allegedly performed a number of political motivated assassinations against dissidents and [[politics of Iran|opposition leaders]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Bakhtiar, Teymour|url=http://www.bakhtiarifamily.com/teymourintro.php|publisher=Bakhtiari Family|access-date=4 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170804113450/http://www.bakhtiarifamily.com/teymourintro.php|archive-date=4 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Use by Israel === {{main|Israeli targeted killings}} According to [[Ronen Bergman]], "since World War II, Israel has used assassination and targeted-killing more than any other country in the West, in many cases endangering the lives of civilians."<ref>[[Ronen Bergman]], [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/23/magazine/how-arafat-eluded-israels-assassination-machine.html 'How Arafat Eluded Israel’s Assassination Machine,'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180507125757/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/23/magazine/how-arafat-eluded-israels-assassination-machine.html |date=7 May 2018 }} [[New York Times Magazine]] 23 January 2018</ref>
During the [[First Intifada]] Palestinian uprising, the Palestinian human-rights group [[Al Haq]] condemned Israeli soldiers for what they described as "deliberate, cold-blooded... targeted" killings of Palestinians in the [[West Bank]] and [[Gaza Strip]].<ref name=xinhua90>{{cite news |title= Israeli soldiers condemned for wilful killings of palestinians |publisher= Xinhua General News Service |date= 20 February 1990}}</ref> The human rights group, Middle East Watch, alleged in 1993 that interviewed Israeli soldiers had targeted often unarmed Palestinians, some under the age of 16, for "premeditated assassinations" or targeted killing, a charge denied by Israeli officials.<ref name=AFP93>{{cite news |title= Undercover troops have 'licence to kill' Palestinians: rights group |agency= Agence France-Presse |date=29 June 1993}}</ref> The allegations included the execution of Palestinians in custody.<ref>{{cite news |title=Israeli undercover units ordered to shoot to kill, says report |work=The Guardian |author= Derek Brown |date=30 June 1993}}</ref>
Controversy over targeted killings continued during the [[Second Intifada]]. Palestinians charged that individuals belonging to the group [[Hamas]] and shot in targeted killings were being assassinated; Israeli stated that those killed were responsible for attacks against Israelis.<ref name=AP00>{{cite news |title= Israelis kill Palestinian in a car; Palestinians call it an assassination |agency= Associated Press |author= Mark Lavie |date=14 December 2000}}</ref> Israeli officials initially accepted responsibility for only some of the killings, and Israeli media termed the practice a "liquidations policy", whereas Palestinians called it "state terrorism".<ref name=NPR01>{{cite news |title= Israel's policy of targeted assassinations of alleged militant palestinians |publisher=NPR |author= Jennifer Ludden |date= 2 January 2001}}</ref> In January 2001 Israeli officials confirmed "the practice of targeted assassinations".<ref name=wpost01>{{cite news |title= Israelis Confirm Assassinations Used as Policy; Key Palestinians Targeted |work= The Washington Post |accessdate= 20 September 2012 |author= Keith B. Richburg |date= 8 January 2001 |url= http://www.radioislam.org/historia/zionism/liquidationpolicy.html |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130117085210/http://radioislam.org/historia/zionism/liquidationpolicy.html# |archive-date= 17 January 2013 |dead-url= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> Conflict in Israeli over the legality of the practice centered on the case of Dr. Thabet Thabet, assassinated as he left his home on New Year's Eve. Dr. Thabet was alleged by the Israeli military to be a senior local leader of [[Fatah]] and plotting attacks against Israelis in the [[West Bank]]. A dentist, Dr. Thabet was also a friend of many Israeli peace activists and considered one himself. Israeli activists called the killing "a crime", "Mafia-style", and "immoral". [[Ephraim Sneh]], then Israeli Deputy Prime Minister, described the policy as "effective, precise and just".<ref name=wpost01 />
The ''[[Washington Post]]'' commented that Israeli policy of targeted killing during the Second Intifada expanded upon previous policies, targeting not only terrorists but also those thought to direct or coordinate them.<ref name=wpost01 /> Another controversial killing, which occurred following the Bush Administration's condemnation of the practice, was that of Mahmoud Madani, a leader of Hamas shot while leaving a mosque in the Balata refugee camp. The Israeli military suspected Madani of plotting bombings in Israel.<ref name=APd01>{{cite news |title= Key Hamas Leader is Slain |accessdate= 20 September 2012 |agency= Associated Press |date= 1 August 2001 |url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4605511.html |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20161018224756/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-4605511.html |archive-date= 18 October 2016 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
At that time, spokesman for the U.S. State Department [[Richard Boucher]] condemned both violence by Palestinians and targeted killings by Israelis during a State Department news briefing.<ref name=APb01>{{cite news |title= Sharon emissaries hold talks with Bush administration officials |publisher= Associated Press Worldstream |author= Barry Schweid |date=13 February 2001}}</ref> U.S. Secretary of State [[Colin Powell]] registered his opposition to "a policy of targeted killings" and the U.S. State Department urged Israel to stop them.<ref name=APc01>{{cite news |title= Bush urges Mideast parties to end violence |agency=Associated Press |author= Barry Schweid |date= 14 February 2001}}</ref>
Then [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] senator [[Joseph Biden]] criticized the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|George W. Bush Administration]] for condemning the targeted killings; the administration continued to oppose them.<ref name=jpost01>{{cite news |title= Sen. Biden defends targeted killings |newspaper= The Jerusalem Post|author= Janine Zacharia |date= 3 August 2001}}</ref>

===Philippines=== In the [[Philippines]], since [[Rodrigo Duterte]] assumption of the presidency in 2016, police and vigilantes have targeted drug related criminal suspects, with many cases, some involving children, thought to be the result of police extrajudicial executions.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/09/09/philippines-abusive-drug-war-targets-children Philippines: Abusive ‘Drug War’ Targets Children 2 New Summary Killings Heighten Urgency of UN Inquiry,''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180101003700/https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/09/09/philippines-abusive-drug-war-targets-children |date=1 January 2018 }}[[Human Right Watch]] 9 September 2017</ref> The group [[Human Rights Watch]] has described these [[extrajudicial killing]]s as "targeted killings".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=iIxdqgG0EwgC&pg=PA4 "You Can Die Any Time"] [[Human Rights Watch]] April 2009.</ref><ref>[https://www.hrw.org/report/2017/03/02/license-kill/philippine-police-killings-dutertes-war-drugs '“License to Kill” Philippine Police Killings in Duterte’s “War on Drugs”,'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206231849/https://www.hrw.org/report/2017/03/02/license-kill/philippine-police-killings-dutertes-war-drugs |date=6 December 2017 }} 2 March 2017 :’“If by chance that God will place me there, watch out because the 1,000 [people allegedly executed while Duterte was mayor of Davao City] will become 100,000. You will see the fish in Manila Bay getting fat. That is where I will dump you.”(b).’ Since taking office, Duterte has repeatedly vowed to kill drug dealers and users in the midst of skyrocketing reports of extrajudicial executions by the police and so-called vigilantes. On August 6, he warned drug dealers: “My order is shoot to kill you. I don’t care about human rights, you better believe me.” He praised the soaring body count of victims of police killings as proof of the “success” of his “war on drugs.”</ref><ref>[https://www.amnesty.org/download/Documents/ASA3555172017ENGLISH.PDF Philippines: "If you are poor, you are killed": Extrajudicial Killings in the Philippines' "War on Drugs"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314051855/https://www.amnesty.org/download/Documents/ASA3555172017ENGLISH.PDF |date=14 March 2017 }} [[Amnesty International]] 31 January 2017,</ref><ref>Rishi Iyengar, [http://time.com/4462352/rodrigo-duterte-drug-war-drugs-philippines-killing/ The Killing Time: Inside Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's War on Drugs] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220235438/http://time.com/4462352/rodrigo-duterte-drug-war-drugs-philippines-killing/ |date=20 December 2017 }} [[Time Magazine]] 25 August 2016: 'one of the first of nearly 2,000 Filipinos killed so far in Duterte’s brutal war on drugs. The carnage is exactly what Duterte promised. “All of you who are into drugs, you sons of bitches, I will really kill you,” he said before his election, in April. A month later, when he was President-elect, Duterte offered medals and cash rewards for citizens that shot dealers dead. “Do your duty, and if in the process you kill 1,000 persons because you were doing your duty, I will protect you,” he told police officers on July 1, the day after his inauguration. He was speaking at a ceremony installing dela Rosa, his loyal henchman, as the nation’s top cop. “If you know of any addicts, go ahead and kill them yourself as getting their parents to do it would be too painful,” he was quoted as saying to another crowd that day.’</ref>
===Syria=== During a 2016 visit to [[Damascus]], British statesman [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] was shown by Syria's [[Bashar al-Assad]] a spreadsheet outlining the identities of 783 whose targeted killing he had approved.<ref name="CSS" />
== Europe == === In Bosnia and Serbia === Referring to human rights abuses during the [[Bosnian War]], the U.S. State Department noted politically or ethnically motivated "targeted killings" in Bosnia in Section 1a., "Political and Other Extrajudicial Killing", of its 1993 report on human rights practices in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].<ref name=DSD93>{{cite news |title=BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA Human Rights Practices, 1992 |publisher= Department of State Dispatch |id= Accessed 20 September 2012 |author= Department of State |date=March 1993}}</ref>{{Verify source|date=March 2015}} Targeted killings were also reported by Serbian and Albanian forces during the [[Kosovo War]].<ref name=NYT99>{{cite news |title=US pushes plans to end fighting in Serb province |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/28/world/us-pushes-plan-to-end-fighting-in-serb-province.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=20 September 2012 |author=Jane Perlez |date=28 January 1999 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617122817/http://www.nytimes.com/1999/01/28/world/us-pushes-plan-to-end-fighting-in-serb-province.html |archive-date=17 June 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Both wars involved large scale targeted killings of journalists.<ref name=IPS99>{{cite news|title=Rights: Journalists "first target" in conflicts, IFJ says|publisher=Inter Press Service|accessdate=20 September 2012|author=Niccolo Sarno|date=22 December 1999|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/1999/12/rights-journalists-first-target-in-conflicts-ifj-says/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402094242/http://www.ipsnews.net/1999/12/rights-journalists-first-target-in-conflicts-ifj-says/|archive-date=2 April 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
=== Use by the Russian government === During the [[First Chechen War]], Chechen President [[Dzhokhar Dudaev]] was killed on 21 April 1996 by two [[laser-guided]] [[missile]]s when he was using a [[satellite phone]], after his location was detected by a Russian [[reconnaissance aircraft]], which intercepted his phone call.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20120105203129/http://www.ericmargolis.com/political_commentaries/time-to-set-the-chechen-free.aspx</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Eric S. Margolis |date=5 April 2010 |title=Time to Set the Chechen Free |url=http://www.ericmargolis.com/political_commentaries/time-to-set-the-chechen-free.aspx |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120105203129/http://www.ericmargolis.com/political_commentaries/time-to-set-the-chechen-free.aspx |archivedate= 5 January 2012}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2015}}
On 20 March 2002, [[Ibn al-Khattab]], who led his militia against Russian forces in Chechnya during the [[First Chechen War|First]] and [[Second Chechen War]], setting up many effective [[ambush]]es against Russian forces as well as managing the influx of foreign fighters and money, was killed when a [[Dagestan]]i messenger hired by the Russian [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|FSB]] gave Khattab a [[poison]]ed letter. Chechen sources said that the letter was coated with "a fast-acting nerve agent, possibly [[sarin]] or a [[derivative]]".<ref>{{cite journal |url= http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hsp/bulletin/cbwcb56.pdf |title= The chemical weapons convention and OPCW: the challenges of the 21st century |author= Ian R Kenyon |date= June 2002 |journal= The CBW Conventions Bulletin |publisher= Harvard Sussex Program on CBW Armament and Arms Limitation |issue= 56 |page= 47 |access-date= 4 October 2014 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924032450/http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hsp/bulletin/cbwcb56.pdf |archive-date= 24 September 2015 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref>
On 13 February 2004, [[Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev]], who served as acting president of the breakaway [[Chechen Republic of Ichkeria]] between 1996 and 1997, was killed when a bomb ripped through his [[Sport utility vehicle|SUV]] in the [[Qatar]]i capital, [[Doha]]. Yandarbiyev was seriously wounded and died in hospital. His 13-year-old son Daud was seriously injured.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/feb/14/chechnya.nickpatonwalsh "Top Chechen separatist dies in Qatar bomb blast"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529061150/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2004/feb/14/chechnya.nickpatonwalsh |date=29 May 2012 }}, ''[[The Guardian]]'', 14 February 2004</ref> The day after the attack, Qatari authorities arrested three Russians in a Russian embassy villa. One of them, the first secretary of the Russian Embassy in Qatar, Aleksandr Fetisov, was released in March due to his diplomatic status and the remaining two, the GRU agents Anatoly Yablochkov (also known as Belashkov) and Vasily Pugachyov (sometimes misspelled as Bogachyov), were charged with the assassination of Yandarbiyev, an assassination attempt of his son Daud Yandarbiyev, and smuggling weapons into Qatar.<ref>{{ru icon}} [http://lenta.ru/russia/2004/03/03/ivanov/ Sergei Ivanov has promised to strive for discharge of the Russian prisoners in Qatar] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214151922/http://lenta.ru/russia/2004/03/03/ivanov/ |date=14 February 2008 }}, [[Lenta.ru]], 3 March 2004</ref> There were some speculations that Fetisov had been released in exchange for Qatari wrestlers detained in Moscow.<ref>[http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=460638 "Let Go"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606085432/http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=460638 |date=6 June 2011 }}, ''[[Kommersant]]'', 25 March 2004</ref> On 30 June 2004, both Russians were sentenced to [[life imprisonment]]; passing the sentence, the judge stated that they had acted on orders from the Russian leadership.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3852697.stm "Russia 'behind Chechen murder'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070308221547/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3852697.stm |date=8 March 2007 }}, [[BBC News]], 30 June 2004</ref><ref>[http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=552963 Aslan Maskhadov Killed] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527062651/http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=552963 |date=27 May 2007 }}, ''[[Kommersant]]'', 9 March 2005</ref><ref>{{ru icon}} [http://www.gazeta.ru/2004/04/29/oa_119495.shtml Задержанные в Катаре – офицеры ГРУ] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095920/http://www.gazeta.ru/2004/04/29/oa_119495.shtml |date=6 October 2014 }}, [[Gazeta.ru]], 29 April 2004</ref> But on 23 December 2004, Qatar agreed to extradite the prisoners to Russia, where they would serve out their life sentences. The agents however received a heroes' welcome on returning to Moscow in January 2005 but disappeared from public view shortly afterwards. The Russian prison authorities admitted in February 2005 that they were not in jail, but said that a sentence handed down in Qatar was "irrelevant" in Russia.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4275147.stm "Convicted Russia agents 'missing'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029130004/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4275147.stm |date=29 October 2008 }}, [[BBC News]], 17 February 2005</ref>
On 10 July 2006 [[Shamil Basayev]], a Chechen militant leader who was alleged to be responsible for numerous guerrilla attacks on security forces in and around Chechnya<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kavkaz.org.uk/eng/content/2005/09/16/4074.shtml |title=Russia's tactics make Chechen war spread across Caucasus |publisher=Kavkaz |date=16 September 2005 |accessdate=4 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140101173754/http://www.kavkaz.org.uk/eng/content/2005/09/16/4074.shtml |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2005/7/C7FD0FF2-647F-42EA-827B-42812C1E8A0A.html |title= Russia: RFE/RL Interviews Chechen Field Commander Umarov |publisher= Rferl |date= 28 July 2005 |accessdate= 4 November 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080617083830/http://www.rferl.org/featuresarticle/2005/7/C7FD0FF2-647F-42EA-827B-42812C1E8A0A.html |archive-date= 17 June 2008 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2373424 No Terrorist Acts in Russia Since Beslan: Whom to Thank?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918223149/http://www.jamestown.org/chechnya_weekly/article.php?articleid=2373424 |date=18 September 2008 }}</ref> and the 2002 [[Moscow theater hostage crisis]] and described by [[ABC News]] as "one of the most-wanted terrorists in the world",<ref name=most_wanted>{{cite news |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/story?id=989549&page=1 |title= Chechen Guerilla Leader Calls Russians 'Terrorists' |date=28 July 2005 |accessdate= 30 March 2010 |publisher= ABC News}}</ref> was killed by an explosion near the border of [[North Ossetia]] in the village of Ali-Yurt, [[Ingushetia]], a republic bordering Chechnya. According to the official version of Basayev's death, the [[Federal Security Service|FSB]], following him with a [[Unmanned aerial vehicle|drone]], spotted his car approach a truck laden with explosives that the FSB had prepared, and by remote control triggered a [[detonator]] in the explosives.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/07/10/russia.basayev/index.html |work= CNN |title= Mastermind of Russian school siege killed; Report: Chechen warlord dies in blast set by Russian agents |date= 10 July 2006 |accessdate= 23 May 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090121173606/http://www.cnn.com/2006/WORLD/europe/07/10/russia.basayev/index.html |archive-date= 21 January 2009 |dead-url= no |df= dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.runewsweek.ru/theme/?tid=73&rid=1229 |script-title=ru:''Ликвидация с вариациями'' |work=Russian Newsweek |date=23 July 2006 |language=ru |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020301/http://www.runewsweek.ru/theme/?tid=73&rid=1229 |archivedate=28 September 2007}}</ref>
[[Alexander Litvinenko]] was poisoned with [[polonium]], which a public inquiry in the UK concluded was carried out by [[Federal Security Service|FSB]] agents.

== Legality == === Legal justifications for targeted killing === The [[U.S. Army]]'s ''Law of Land Warfare'' (Field Manual 27-10) states: <blockquote>
31. Assassination and Outlawry
It is especially forbidden * * * to kill or wound treacherously individuals belonging to the hostile nation or army. [Article 23(b) of the [[Hague Convention of 1907|1907 Hague Regulations]]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v2_cou_us_rule65_sectionb |title=United States of America Practice Relating to Rule 65. Perfidy Section B. Killing, injuring or capturing an adversary by resort to perfidy |publisher=[[International Committee of the Red Cross]] |access-date=11 December 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215054118/http://www.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/v2_cou_us_rule65_sectionb |archive-date=15 December 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
This article is construed as prohibiting assassination, proscription, or outlawry of an enemy, or putting a price upon an enemy's head, as well as offering a reward for an enemy "dead or alive". It does not, however, preclude attacks on individual soldiers or officers of the enemy whether in the zone of hostilities, occupied territory, or elsewhere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/policy/army/fm/27-10/Ch2.htm|title=FM 27-10 Chptr 2 Hostilities|author=John Pike|publisher=|accessdate=15 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205001151/http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/policy/army/fm/27-10/Ch2.htm|archive-date=5 February 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> </blockquote>
Daniel Reisner, who headed the International Legal Division of the Israeli Military Advocate General's Office from 1994 to 2005,<ref name="ReisnerProfile">{{cite web|url=http://www.martindale.com/Daniel-Reisner/26213772-lawyer.htm|title=Daniel Reisner's Profile|publisher=martindale.com|accessdate=31 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617052116/http://www.martindale.com/Daniel-Reisner/26213772-lawyer.htm|archive-date=17 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> has stated that although targeted killing is illegal under previous understanding of international law, "If you do something for long enough, the world will accept it. The whole of international law is now based on the notion that an act that is forbidden today becomes permissible if executed by enough countries."<ref name="HaaretzReisner">''[http://www.haaretz.com/consent-and-advise-1.269127 Consent and advise] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130130113612/http://www.haaretz.com/consent-and-advise-1.269127 |date=30 January 2013 }}'', Yotam Feldman and Uri Blau, ''[[Haaretz]]'', 29 January 2009.</ref> Reisner continues, "International law progresses through violations. We invented the targeted assassination thesis and we had to push it. At first there were protrusions that made it hard to insert easily into the legal moulds. Eight years later it is in the center of the bounds of legitimacy."<ref name="HaaretzReisner"/> This view is disputed by George Bisharat of the University of California's Hastings College of the Law, who contends that assassination is not widely regarded as legal.<ref name="BisharatNYT">''[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/30/opinion/why-palestine-should-take-israel-to-court-in-the-hague.html Why Palestine Should Take Israel to Court in The Hague] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322024134/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/30/opinion/why-palestine-should-take-israel-to-court-in-the-hague.html |date=22 March 2017 }}'', George Bisharat, ''[[The New York Times]]'', 31 January 2013.</ref>
[[Georgetown University Law Center|Georgetown Law]] Professor and former [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine]], [[Gary D. Solis|Gary Solis]], has argued that under certain conditions, "[[Assassination]]s and targeted killings are very different acts."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6FKf0ocxEPAC&lpg=PP1&dq=The%20Law%20of%20Armed%20Conflict%3A%20International%20Humanitarian%20Law%20in%20War&pg=PA542#v=onepage&q=targeted%20killings%20are%20very%20different%20acts&f=false |title=The Law of Armed Conflict: International Humanitarian Law in War |author=Gary D. Solis |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2010 |isbn=9781139487115 |page=542 |accessdate=5 August 2012}}</ref> For Solis, these conditions require that there is an ongoing military conflict, the targeted individual (civilian or military) has taken up arms, that there is no reasonable possibility of arrest, and that the decision to kill is made by senior political leaders.<ref name="google1"/>
[[Abraham David Sofaer|Abraham Sofaer]], a former legal advisor to the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] and fellow at the conservative [[Hoover Institution]] think tank, has written that targeted killing is "sometimes necessary, because leaders are obliged to defend their citizens". After the killing of [[Hamas]] founder and [[quadriplegic]] [[Ahmed Yassin]] by Israeli helicopter gunships, Sofaer argued that targeted killing is not prohibited by American [[Executive Order 11905]] banning assassination: "killings in self-defense are no more 'assassinations' in international affairs than they are murders when undertaken by our police forces against domestic killers."<ref name="HOV">[http://www.sfgate.com/opinion/openforum/article/Responses-to-Terrorism-Targeted-killing-is-a-2775845.php "Targeted killing is a necessary option"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130618095718/http://www.sfgate.com/opinion/openforum/article/Responses-to-Terrorism-Targeted-killing-is-a-2775845.php |date=18 June 2013 }}, Sofaer, Abraham D., [[Hoover Institution]], 26 March 2004</ref>
Sofaer had previously argued during the [[First Gulf War]] that targeted killing was ethical but impractical: "Targeted killing will also invite revenge against the leaders who order it as well as their citizens and property. Given the legal, political and moral constraints that limit such activities in democratic regimes, the United States has a substantial interest in discouraging acceptance of the killing of political leaders as a routine measure, even in self-defense."<ref name=USN&WR>{{cite news |title=Thinking past the moment|work=U.S. News & World Report|author=Abarham D. Sofaer|date=18 February 1991}}</ref>
Author and former [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] Captain Matthew J. Morgan has argued, "there is a major difference between assassination and targeted killing.... targeted killing [is] not synonymous with assassination. Assassination ... constitutes an illegal killing."<ref>{{cite book |author=Matthew J. Morgan |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QP1Bq7HVQtwC&dq=The+Impact+of+9/11+and+the+New+Legal+Landscape:+The+Day+That+Changed+Everything&source=gbs_navlinks_s |title=The Impact of 9/11 and the New Legal Landscape: The Day that Changed Everything? |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |year=2009 |accessdate=5 August 2012 |ISBN=978-0-230-60838-2 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622104407/http://books.google.com/books?id=QP1Bq7HVQtwC&dq=The+Impact+of+9%2F11+and+the+New+Legal+Landscape%3A+The+Day+That+Changed+Everything&source=gbs_navlinks_s |archive-date=22 June 2013 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}{{page needed|date=August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QP1Bq7HVQtwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Impact+of+9/11+and+the+New+Legal+Landscape:+The+Day+That+Changed+Everything&source=bl&ots=wJJzz_X2WQ&sig=dfBVA1xydinRGtvSn5-3KbQloGs&hl=en&ei=2szrS6WOK4Sdlgenq-y1CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=major%20difference%20between%20assassination%20and%20targeted%20killing&f=false|author=Matthew J. Morgan|title=The Impact of 9–11: The New Legal Landscape|ISBN=978-0-230-60838-2|publisher=Macmillan|year=2009|accessdate=29 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623035812/http://books.google.com/books?id=QP1Bq7HVQtwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Impact+of+9%2F11+and+the+New+Legal+Landscape%3A+The+Day+That+Changed+Everything&source=bl&ots=wJJzz_X2WQ&sig=dfBVA1xydinRGtvSn5-3KbQloGs&hl=en&ei=2szrS6WOK4Sdlgenq-y1CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=major%20difference%20between%20assassination%20and%20targeted%20killing&f=false|archive-date=23 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}{{page needed|date=August 2016}}</ref> [[Amos Guiora]], formerly an [[Israel Defense Forces]] Lt. Colonol and commander of the IDF school of military law, now Professor of law at the University of Utah, has written, "targeted killing is ... not an assassination". [[Steven R. David|Steve David]], [[Johns Hopkins University|Johns Hopkins]] Associate Dean & Professor of International Relations, writes: "there are strong reasons to believe that the Israeli policy of targeted killing is not the same as assassination." [[Syracuse University College of Law|Syracuse Law]] Professor William Banks and [[George Washington University Law School|GW Law]] Professor Peter Raven-Hansen write: "Targeted killing of terrorists is ... not unlawful and would not constitute assassination." Rory Miller writes: "Targeted killing ... is not 'assassination'", and associate professor Eric Patterson and Teresa Casale write: "Perhaps most important is the legal distinction between targeted killing and assassination."<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/cwrint36&div=20&id=&page= |author=[[Amos Guiora]] |title=Targeted Killing as Active Self-Defense |journal=Case Western Reserve Journal of International Law |volume=36 |issue=319 |year=2004 |accessdate=29 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114062931/http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals%2Fcwrint36&div=20&id=&page= |archive-date=14 January 2015 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://biu.ac.il/SOC/besa/david.pdf |author=[[Steven R. David]] |title=Fatal Choices: Israel's Policy Of Targeted Killing |publisher=The Begin-Sadat Center for Strategic Studies |format=PDF |date=September 2002 |accessdate=29 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116182446/http://www.biu.ac.il/SOC/besa/david.pdf |archivedate=16 November 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name="google3">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i5lnAAAAMAAJ&q=assassination+%22targeted+killing%22&dq=assassination+%22targeted+killing%22&hl=en&ei=9dDrS8z2JIH7lwf_84i1CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=13&ved=0CGAQ6AEwDA|author=Rory Miller|title=Ireland and the Middle East: trade, society and peace|publisher=Irish Academic Press|ISBN=978-0-7165-2868-5|year=2007|accessdate=29 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623041336/http://books.google.com/books?id=i5lnAAAAMAAJ&q=assassination+%22targeted+killing%22&dq=assassination+%22targeted+killing%22&hl=en&ei=9dDrS8z2JIH7lwf_84i1CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=13&ved=0CGAQ6AEwDA|archive-date=23 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="google3"/><ref>[http://heinonlinebackup.com/hol-cgi-bin/get_pdf.cgi?handle=hein.journals/urich37&section=31 "Targeted Killing and Assassination: The U.S. Legal Framework"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010072758/http://heinonlinebackup.com/hol-cgi-bin/get_pdf.cgi?handle=hein.journals%2Furich37&section=31 |date=10 October 2017 }}, Banks, William C., Raven-Hansen, Peter, 37 ''University of Richmond Law Review'' 667 (2002–03). Retrieved 9 October 2010.</ref>
American defense department analyst and professor Thomas Hunter has defined targeted killing as the "premeditated, preemptive, and intentional killing of an individual or individuals known or believed to represent a present or future threat to the safety and security of a state through the affiliation with terrorist groups or individuals.<ref name="target_killing">{{cite book|title=Targeted Killing: Self-Defense, Preemption and the War on Terrorism|author= Thomas B. Hunter|year=2009|isbn= 1-4392-5205-X}}</ref> Hunter writes that the target is a person who is allegedly taking part in an armed conflict or terrorism, whether by bearing arms or otherwise, who has allegedly lost the immunity from being targeted that he would otherwise have under the [[Third Geneva Convention]].<ref name="google1"/> Hunter distinguishes between "targeted killing" and "targeted violence" as used by specialists who study [[violence]].
In response to the terrorist attacks on 9/11, the [[Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Terrorists|Authorization for Use of Military Force]] (AUMF) stated on 14 September 2001, "That the President is authorized to use all necessary and appropriate force against those nations, organizations or persons he determines planned, authorized, harbored, committed, or aided in the planning or commission of the attacks against the United States that occurred on 11 September 2001, and to deter and pre-empt any future acts of terrorism or aggression against the United States".<ref name="law.umaryland.edu">{{cite web|last=Grimmett|first=R.|title=CRS Report for Congress|url=http://www.law.umaryland.edu/marshall/crsreports/crsdocuments/RS22357_01042006.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=law.umaryland.edu|access-date=14 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103190049/http://www.law.umaryland.edu/marshall/crsreports/crsdocuments/RS22357_01042006.pdf|archive-date=3 November 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This authorization is still in effect today.<ref>''The Hill'': [http://blogs.rollcall.com/white-house/obama-has-authority-to-bomb-iraq-without-congress-because-aumf-never-expired/?dcz= "Obama Could Bomb Iraq Without Congress Because War Authorization Never Expired"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150608090244/http://blogs.rollcall.com/white-house/obama-has-authority-to-bomb-iraq-without-congress-because-aumf-never-expired/?dcz= |date=8 June 2015 }} 12 June 2014. Accessed 17 February 2015.</ref> There are no restrictions regarding the physical location of where this law is applied. It only states that the President has the "authority to use all necessary and appropriate force" this could be interpreted to mean that the President can attack al-Qaeda anywhere in the world.<ref name="law.umaryland.edu"/>
=== Legal opposition === During the [[1998 bombing of Iraq]], ''[[The Scotsman]]'' reported, "US law prohibits the targeted killing of foreign leaders... Administration officials have been careful to say they will not expressly aim to kill Saddam."<ref name=Scotsman98>{{cite news |last=Branson |first=Louise |date=14 November 1998 |title=Campaign to eliminate Saddam gains speed |newspaper=The Scotsman |accessdate=20 September 2012 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-18675087.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202235638/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-18675087.html |archive-date=2 February 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Frank Sauer and Niklas Schoernig have described targeted killing as a violation of international law and a contravention of domestic laws,<ref name="SauerSchoernigKillerDrones">Sauer, Frank/Schoernig Niklas, 2012: [http://sdi.sagepub.com/content/43/4/363.abstract "Killer drones: The 'silver bullet' of democratic warfare?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817232308/http://sdi.sagepub.com/content/43/4/363.abstract |date=17 August 2012 }}, in: ''Security Dialogue'' 43 (4): 363-380, accessed 1 September 2012.</ref> and maintain that the term itself is merely a legitimized euphemism for [[assassination]].
The American Civil Liberties Union states in its website, "A program of targeted killing far from any battlefield, without charge or trial, violates the constitutional guarantee of due process. It also violates international law, under which lethal force may be used outside armed conflict zones only as a last resort to prevent imminent threats, when non-lethal means are not available. Targeting people who are suspected of terrorism for execution, far from any war zone, turns the whole world into a battlefield."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.aclu.org/national-security/frequently-asked-questions-about-targeting-killing |title=Frequently Asked Questions About Targeting Killing |publisher=American Civil Liberties Union |date=30 August 2010 |accessdate=5 August 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120811144919/http://www.aclu.org/national-security/frequently-asked-questions-about-targeting-killing |archive-date=11 August 2012 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Yael Stein, the research director of B'Tselem, The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, also states in her article "By Any Name Illegal and Immoral: Response to 'Israel's Policy of Targeted Killing'": <blockquote>The argument that this policy affords the public a sense of revenge and retribution could serve to justify acts both illegal and immoral. Clearly, lawbreakers ought to be punished. Yet, no matter how horrific their deeds, as the targeting of Israeli civilians indeed is, they should be punished according to the law. David's arguments could, in principle, justify the abolition of formal legal systems altogether.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegiecouncil.org/resources/journal/17_1/debate/860.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20120314201721/http%3A//www%2Ecarnegiecouncil%2Eorg/resources/journal/17_1/debate/860%2Ehtml |archivedate=14 March 2012 |df= }}</ref></blockquote> In 2001, Ibrahim Nafie criticized the U.S. for agreeing with "the Israeli spin that calls ... its official policy of assassinating Palestinian leaders 'targeted killing'."<ref>{{cite news |author=Ibrahim Nafie |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/557/op1.htm |title=Opinion | The very model of a rogue state |publisher=[[Al-Ahram Weekly]] |date=31 October 2001 |accessdate=20 May 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123173834/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/557/op1.htm# |archive-date=23 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2013, [[United Nations Special Rapporteur]] on human rights and counter terrorism, [[Ben Emmerson]], stated that U.S. drone strikes may have violated [[international humanitarian law]].<ref>"[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/drone-strikes-us-violate-law-un Drone strikes by US may violate international law, says UN ] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130214320/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/oct/18/drone-strikes-us-violate-law-un |date=30 November 2016 }}". ''The Guardian.'' 18 October 2013.</ref><ref>"[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/10/un-report-independent-investigations-drone-attacks UN report calls for independent investigations of drone attacks] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324224410/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/10/un-report-independent-investigations-drone-attacks |date=24 March 2018 }}". ''The Guardian.'' 18 October 2013.</ref>
=== Additional concerns === For drone strikes to be effective, the United States must obtain consent from the host country they are operating in. The growing chorus of objections from host countries, most notably emanating from Pakistan, seriously inhibits drones’ effectiveness.<ref name="Micah January 2013 3">{{cite book|last=Micah|first=Zenko|title=Reforming U.S. Drone Strike Policies|date=January 2013|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|location=New York|page=3|url=http://www.cfr.org/wars-and-warfare/reforming-us-drone-strike-policies/p29736|access-date=11 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206074451/http://www.cfr.org/wars-and-warfare/reforming-us-drone-strike-policies/p29736|archive-date=6 February 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> "Host states have grown frustrated with U.S. drone policy, while opposition by non-host partners could impose additional restrictions on the use of drones. Reforming U.S. drone strike policies can do much to allay concerns internationally by ensuring that targeted killings are defensible under international legal regimes that the United States itself helped establish and by allowing U.S. officials to openly address concerns and counter misinformation."<ref name="Micah January 2013 3"/> [[Micah Zenko]] at the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] believes the United States should "end so-called signature strikes, which target unidentified militants based on their behavior patterns and personal networks, and limit targeted killings to a small number of specific terrorists with transnational ambitions.<ref name="Micah January 2013 vii">{{cite book|last=Micah|first=Zenko|title=Reforming U.S. Drone Strike Policies|date=January 2013|publisher=Council on Foreign Relations|location=New York, New York|pages=vii|url=http://www.cfr.org/wars-and-warfare/reforming-us-drone-strike-policies/p29736|access-date=11 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206074451/http://www.cfr.org/wars-and-warfare/reforming-us-drone-strike-policies/p29736|archive-date=6 February 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He wants more congressional oversight of drone strikes and stricter regulation on armed drone sales. Finally, he recommends the United States work with international partners to establish rules and norms governing the use of drones.<ref name="Micah January 2013 vii"/> Zenko believes the U.S. government has not been transparent regarding how non-battlefield drone strikes are reconciled with broader foreign policy objectives, the scope of legitimate targets, and their legal framework.<ref name="Micah January 2013 3"/> While drones may be a critical counterterrorism tool that advances U.S. interests, their "lack of transparency threatens to limit U.S. freedom of action and risks proliferation of armed drone technology without the requisite normative framework."<ref name="Micah January 2013 3" /> Zenko thinks current drone policy might share the same fate of the Bush-era [[enhanced interrogation techniques]] and [[warrantless wiretapping]], both of which were unpopular, illegal and ultimately ended.{{Citation needed|reason=reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=May 2014}}
[[Harvard Law School]] Professors Gabriella Blum and Philip Heymann cite six potential hazards of targeted killings: First, the so-called [[Hydra effect]], or the rise of more—and more resolute—leaders to replace those who were recently "decapitated."<ref name="Blum 2010 p. 165">{{cite journal|last=Blum|first=Gabriella and Philip Heymann|title=Law and Policy of Targeted Killing|journal=Harvard National Security Journal|date=June 2010|volume=1|page=165|url=http://harvardnsj.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/Vol-1_Blum-Heymann_Final.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907054210/http://harvardnsj.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/Vol-1_Blum-Heymann_Final.pdf|archive-date=7 September 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Second, drones can drive terrorist leaders into hiding, making the monitoring of their movements, and subsequent intelligence gathering, extremely difficult.<ref name="Blum 2010 p. 165" /> Third, "the political message flowing from the use of targeted killings may be harmful to the attacking country’s interest, as it emphasizes the disparity in power between the parties and reinforces popular support for the terrorists, who are seen as a David fighting Goliath."<ref name="Blum 2010 p. 165" /> Fourth, when conducted in a foreign country, drone strikes run the risk of heightening tensions between the targeting government and the government in whose territory the operation is conducted.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Blum|first=Gabriella and Philip Heymann|title=Law and Policy of Targeted Killing|journal=Harvard National Security Journal|date=June 2010|volume=1|page=166|url=http://harvardnsj.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/Vol-1_Blum-Heymann_Final.pdf|accessdate=11 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120907054210/http://harvardnsj.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/06/Vol-1_Blum-Heymann_Final.pdf|archive-date=7 September 2012|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Fifth, targeted killings threaten criticism from local domestic constituencies against the government allowing strikes within their country.<ref name="Blum 2010 p. 165" /> Finally, there is a danger of over-using targeted killings, both within and outside the war of terrorism.<ref name="Blum 2010 p. 165"/>
Daniel Byman, security studies professor at [[Georgetown University]], argues that [[Federal government of the United States|Washington]] must clarify its policies behind extrajudicial and extraterritorial killings, lest a nefarious precedent in [[international law]] is set.<ref name=Byman>{{cite journal|last=Byman|first=Daniel|title=Why Drones Work: The Case for Washington's Weapon of Choice|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=July–August 2013|volume=92|issue=4|url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/articles/2013/06/17-drones-obama-weapon-choice-us-counterterrorism-byman|accessdate=8 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130619152211/http://www.brookings.edu/research/articles/2013/06/17-drones-obama-weapon-choice-us-counterterrorism-byman|archive-date=19 June 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Additionally, Byman argues that Washington must "remain mindful of the built-in limits of low-cost, unmanned interventions, since the very convenience of drone warfare risks dragging the United States into conflicts it could otherwise avoid."<ref name=Byman /> Though Byman recognizes the problems inherent in using armed UAVs, he believes that they are very effective. "U.S. drones have killed an estimated 3,000 [[al Qaeda]], [[Taliban]], and other jihadist operatives in [[Pakistan]] and [[Yemen]]. That number includes over 50 senior leaders of al Qaeda and the Taliban--top figures who are not easily replaced."<ref name=Byman /> Drones have also undercut terrorists' ability to effectively communicate with its target audiences, ultimately straining their recruitment pools. To avoid attracting drones, al Qaeda operates have avoided gathering in large numbers and mitigated use of electronic devices.<ref name=Byman /> Byman argues that al Qaeda leaders "cannot give orders when they are incommunicado, and training on a large scale is nearly impossible when a drone strike could wipe out an entire coupe of new recruits. Drones have turned al Qaeda's command and training structures into a liability, forcing the group to choose between having no leaders and risking dead leaders."<ref name=Byman />
Audrey Kurth Cronin of [[George Mason University]] argues that while drones are tactically savvy, they have failed to advance the strategic goals of U.S. counter-terrorism policy.<ref name="Cronin FA">{{cite journal|last=Cronin|first=Audrey Kurth|title=Why Drones Fail: When Tactics Drive Strategy|journal=Foreign Affairs|date=July–August 2013|volume=92|issue=4|pages=44–54|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/139454/audrey-kurth-cronin/why-drones-fail|accessdate=10 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130713065224/http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/139454/audrey-kurth-cronin/why-drones-fail|archive-date=13 July 2013|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Terrorism itself is a tactic, Cronin notes, but it succeeds on a strategic plane when a shocking event is successfully leveraged for political gain.<ref name="Cronin FA" /> "To be effective, counter-terrorism must itself respond with a coherent strategy. The problem for [[Federal government of the United States|Washington]] today is that its drone program has taken on a life of its own, to the point where tactics are driving strategy rather than the other way around."<ref name="Cronin FA" /> Cronin agrees with Daniel Byman of Georgetown University insofar that drones have inflicted real damage upon [[al Qaeda]]. However, "Washington now finds itself in a permanent battle with amorphous and geographically dispersed foe, one with an increasingly marginal connection to the original 9/11 plotters. In this endless contest, the United States risks multiplying its enemies and heightening their incentives to attack the country."<ref name="Cronin FA" />

{{Unbalanced|date=December 2009}} {{Globalize|date=December 2009}} The word '''Type''' followed by a number is a common way to name a weapon or product in a production series, similar in meaning to "[[Mark (designation)|Mark]]". "Type" was used extensively by the Japanese and Chinese militaries beginning in the 1920s, and is still in current use by the militaries of both nations. The United Kingdom uses a '''type number system''' for much of their military equipment. Many other nations use the word "Type" to designate products in a series.
==Japan== The [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] (IJN) began using the Type-Number System in 1921 to designate aircraft accepted for production. The numbers used after the word "Type" were based on the number of years that the [[Emperor Taishō]] had reigned. Since his reign began in 1912, an aircraft ordered into production in 1921 would have been called "Type 10", the tenth year of the emperor's reign. At the end of 1926, the emperor died, leaving his son [[Hirohito]] as the Emperor Shōwa, and the numbering system was reset to mark the new emperor's reign.<ref name=Peattie>{{cite book | last = Peattie | first = Mark R. | authorlink = Mark Peattie | year = 2007 | pages = 302–303 | title = Sunburst: The Rise of Japanese Naval Air Power 1909–1941 | publisher = Naval Institute Press | location = Annapolis, Maryland | isbn = 1-59114-664-X }}</ref>
[[File:Zero Akagi Dec1941.jpg|thumb|The Mitsubishi [[A6M Zero]] was ordered into production in 1940 as the Type 0 Carrier Fighter.]] In 1929, the government of Japan adopted a new system based on the [[Japanese_era_name#Imperial_year|imperial year]].<ref name=Peattie/> Aircraft ordered for production from 1929 onward were assigned the last two digits of the year marking the continuity of Japanese emperors. 1929 was the 2589th imperial year, so aircraft ordered that year were designated "Type 89". 1940 was the 2600th year, and the IJN numbering system was reset to single digits. New aircraft were designated [[0 (number)|0 (zero)]]. The well-known Mitsubishi [[A6M Zero]] was ordered into production in 1940 as the IJN "Type 0 Carrier Fighter" (''Rei shiki Kanjō sentōki'', 零式艦上戦闘機), and was popularly called the "Zero" because of its type.<ref name=Peattie/>
In 1943, the designation system was abandoned by the IJN as it was considered too revealing about the nature of the aircraft. In its place, the aircraft were named with popular terms such as ''Kyōfū'' (強風 "Strong Wind") for the [[Kawanishi N1K]] introduced in 1943.<ref>[[Fred T. Jane|Jane, Frederick Thomas]]. ''Jane's all the world's aircraft, Volume 34'', p. 155c, Jane's Information Group, 1945</ref>
The [[Imperial Japanese Army]] (IJA) began using the Type designation system in 1927, for all weapons, vehicles, military equipment, subassemblies and subsystems such as engines and gunmounts. In 1940, instead of resetting to zero, the IJA assigned "Type 100" to equipment put into production that year. In 1941, the IJA reset to "Type 1". Unlike the IJN, the IJA continued to use the system through 1945 with the production of the [[Kawasaki Ki-100]] Army Type 5 Fighter.<ref>Rickard, J. (2008) History of War. [http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/weapons_japanese_army_aircraft_designations.html ''Japanese Army Air Force Designations of the Second World War''.] Retrieved on December 8, 2009.</ref>
After 1945, Japan's military changed to a numbering system based on the Japanese fiscal year which begins on April 1 in the same manner as the British fiscal year. As an example, "Type 63" was the designation for equipment such as the [[Type 63 AT mine]] accepted in 1963.<ref>Friedman, 1997, p. xl, "Prefatory Notes".</ref>
The [[kanji]] character ''shiki'' (式) is what the Japanese use to designate products in a series. The [[English language]] translation of ''shiki'' has been variously given as "model" or "type".<ref name=Easterly>Easterly, William M. P. (June 2009) [http://www.dragonsoffire.com/ARTICLE:--MODEL---TYPE.php ''Dragons of Fire'', "Model/Type"]. Retrieved on December 8, 2009.</ref> Some manuals and texts have translated ''shiki'' as both "model" and "type" within the same publication, confusing the matter. [[World War II]]-era military dictionaries do not give ''shiki'' as the Japanese word for "model"—instead, the kanji character ''kata'' is given. In turn, ''kata'' (型 or 形) is translated as "form", "type", "pattern", "mark", or "model". The only [[Japanese language]] translation given for the English word "type" is ''shiki''.<ref name=Easterly/>
==China== Chinese weapons and military vehicles are often, but not always, designated according to the [[Gregorian calendar]], the one used by most nations. Two digits are used to designate the year. The two digits appear first, followed by the character ''shi'', meaning "type".<ref>Blasko, Dennis J. ''The Chinese Army today: tradition and transformation for the 21st century'', p. 122. Routledge, 2006. {{ISBN|0-415-77003-3}}</ref> As examples, in 1956, the [[Type 56 assault rifle]] was put into production, and the [[Type 64 pistol]] was designed and approved in 1964.
==United Kingdom== The [[Royal Navy]] uses a type number system where blocks of numbers are reserved for specific purposes. For instance, the block 900–999 was given to naval radar sets beginning in 1945 and continuing for roughly 20 years. Numbers are not always sequential, as the Type 992 target indication radar was developed long before the Type 967 target designation radar. When a reserved block has been fully utilized, another is assigned.<ref>Friedman, 1997, p. xli, "Prefatory Notes".</ref>
==See also== * [[Type system of the Royal Navy]] * [[Japanese military aircraft designation systems]] * [[Joint Electronics Type Designation System]], U.S. military system * [[Mark (designation)]]

{{about|the machine|the Leroy Anderson composition|The Typewriter}} [[Image:Underwoodfive.jpg|thumb|Mechanical desktop typewriters, such as this [[Underwood Typewriter Company|Touchmaster Five]], were long-time standards of government agencies, newsrooms, and offices]]
A '''typewriter''' is a [[Machine (mechanical)|mechanical]] or [[electromechanical]] machine for writing characters similar to those produced by printer's [[movable type]]. Typically, a typewriter has an array of [[Button (control)|keys]], and pressing one causes a different single character to be produced on the paper, by causing a ribbon with dried ink to be struck against the paper by a type element similar to the [[Sort (typesetting)|sorts]] used in [[movable type]] [[letterpress printing]]. Commonly a separate type element (called a typebar) corresponds to each key, but the mechanism may also use a single type element (such as a typeball) with a different portion of it used for each possible character. At the end of the nineteenth century, the term ''typewriter'' was also applied to a person who used a [[typing]] machine.<ref>{{cite OED2|typewriter (2)|volume=Vol 18|page=789}}</ref>
[[File:Typewriter Wiki.webm|thumb|Video on the history of typewriters and how they operate]] The first commercial typewriters were introduced in 1874,<ref>{{cite book|author=James W. Cortada|title=Before the Computer: IBM, NCR, Burroughs, and Remington Rand and the Industry They Created, 1865–1956|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dbl9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT38|year=2015|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-1-4008-7276-3|page=38|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180626060339/https://books.google.com/books?id=dbl9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT38|archivedate=2018-06-26|df=}}</ref> but did not become common in offices until after the mid-1880s.<ref>[https://www.officemuseum.com/typewriters.htm Typewriters - Early Office Museum] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161227181833/http://www.officemuseum.com/typewriters.htm |date=2016-12-27 }}</ref> The typewriter quickly became an indispensable tool for practically all [[writing]] other than personal handwritten correspondence. It was widely used by professional writers, in offices, and for business correspondence in private homes.
[[File:Typewriter.ogv|thumb|Video showing the operation of a typewriter]] [[File:Typewriter(AdlerFavorit)apart.jpg|thumb|right|Disassembled parts of an Adler Favorit mechanical typewriter]] Notable typewriter manufacturers included [[E. Remington and Sons]], [[IBM]], [[Imperial Typewriters]], [[Oliver Typewriter Company]], [[Olivetti]], [[Royal Typewriter Company]], [[Smith Corona]], [[Underwood Typewriter Company]], Adler Typewriter Company and <!--{{Ill|de|Olympia Werke}}-->[[:de:Olympia Werke|Olympia Werke]].<ref group=note>Article about Olympia Werke is available only in German Wikipedia.</ref>
==History== [[File:1864 Schreibmaschine Peter Mitterhofer.jpg|thumb|Peter Mitterhofer's typewriter prototype (1864)]] Although many modern typewriters have one of several similar designs, their invention was incremental, developed by numerous inventors working independently or in competition with each other over a series of decades. As with the [[automobile]], [[telephone]], and [[Telegraphy|telegraph]], a number of people contributed insights and inventions that eventually resulted in ever more commercially successful instruments. Historians have estimated that some form of typewriter was invented 52 times as thinkers tried to come up with a workable design.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Acocella, Joan |title=The Typing Life: How writers used to write |series=[[The New Yorker]] |date=April 9, 2007 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/books/2007/04/09/070409crbo_books_acocella?currentPage=1 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203011413/http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/books/2007/04/09/070409crbo_books_acocella?currentPage=1 |archivedate=December 3, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Early innovations=== Some of the early typing instruments: *In 1575 an [[Italy|Italian]] printmaker, Francesco Rampazetto, invented the ''scrittura tattile'', a machine to impress letters in papers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://museocasertaolivetti.altervista.org/scrittura/|title=Scrittura {{!}} Museo dinamico della tecnologia Adriano Olivetti|last=|first=|date=|website=museocasertaolivetti.altervista.org|language=it-IT|others=https://translate.google.pl/translate?hl=en&sl=it&u=http://museocasertaolivetti.altervista.org/scrittura/&prev=search|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621081930/http://museocasertaolivetti.altervista.org/scrittura/|archive-date=2017-06-21|dead-url=no|access-date=2017-07-21|df=}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} *In 1714, [[Henry Mill]] obtained a patent in Britain for a machine that, from the patent, appears to have been similar to a typewriter. The patent shows that this machine was actually created: "[he] hath by his great study and paines & expence invented and brought to perfection an artificial machine or method for impressing or transcribing of letters, one after another, as in writing, whereby all writing whatsoever may be engrossed in paper or parchment so neat and exact as not to be distinguished from print; that the said machine or method may be of great use in settlements and public records, the impression being deeper and more lasting than any other writing, and not to be erased or counterfeited without manifest discovery."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.todayinsci.com/M/Mill_Henry/MillHenryPatents.htm |title=Henry Mill Patents |publisher=Todayinsci.com |accessdate=2012-03-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128013806/http://www.todayinsci.com/M/Mill_Henry/MillHenryPatents.htm |archivedate=2012-11-28 |df= }}</ref> *In 1802 Italian Agostino Fantoni developed a particular typewriter to enable his [[blindness|blind]] sister to write.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://history-computer.com/ModernComputer/Basis/keyboard.html|title=History of Computers and Computing, Birth of the modern computer, The bases of digital computers, typewriter and computer keyboard|website=history-computer.com|access-date=2016-09-19|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905195941/http://history-computer.com/ModernComputer/Basis/keyboard.html|archivedate=2016-09-05|df=}}</ref> *In 1808 Italian [[Pellegrino Turri]] invented a typewriter. He also invented [[carbon paper]] to provide the ink for his machine.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} *In 1823 Italian Pietro Conti di Cilavegna invented a new model of typewriter, the ''tachigrafo'', also known as ''tachitipo''.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} [[File:Pterotype.jpg|thumb|upright|[[John J. Pratt]]'s "pterotype" (1865)]] *In 1829, American [[William Austin Burt]] patented a machine called the "[[Typographer (typewriter)|Typographer]]" which, in common with many other early machines, is listed as the "first typewriter". The [[Science Museum (London)]] describes it merely as "the first writing mechanism whose invention was documented," but even that claim may be excessive, since Turri's invention pre-dates it.<ref>{{cite book|title=William Austin Burt's Typographer |year=1829 |publisher=Science Museum}}</ref> Even in the hands of its inventor, this machine was slower than handwriting. Burt and his promoter John D. Sheldon never found a buyer for the patent, so the invention was never commercially produced. Because the typographer used a dial, rather than keys, to select each character, it was called an "index typewriter" rather than a "keyboard typewriter." Index typewriters of that era resemble the squeeze-style [[embossing tape|embosser]] from the 1960s more than they resemble the modern keyboard typewriter. By the mid-19th century, the increasing pace of business communication had created a need for mechanization of the writing process. [[Stenographer]]s and [[telegraph]]ers could take down information at rates up to 130 words per minute, whereas a writer with a pen was limited to a maximum of 30 words per minute (the 1853 speed record).<ref name="Utterback">{{cite book | last = Utterback | first = James M. Utterback | authorlink = | title = Mastering The Dynamics Of Innovation, 2nd Ed. | publisher = Harvard Business Press | year = 1996 | location = | isbn = 0875847404}}</ref>
From 1829 to 1870, many printing or typing machines were patented by inventors in Europe and America, but none went into commercial production. {{Citation needed|date=November 2015}} *American [[Charles Thurber (inventor)|Charles Thurber]] developed multiple patents, of which his first in 1843 was developed as an aid to the blind, such as the 1845 [[Charles Thurber (inventor)#Career|Chirographer]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://todayinsci.com/Events/Typewriter/Chirographer-SciAm.htm|title=Thurber’s Chirographer - Scientific American|website=todayinsci.com|access-date=2017-01-20|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327043255/http://todayinsci.com/Events/Typewriter/Chirographer-SciAm.htm|archivedate=2015-03-27|df=}}</ref> *In 1855, the [[Italy|Italian]] [[Giuseppe Ravizza]] created a prototype typewriter called ''Cembalo scrivano o macchina da scrivere a tasti'' ("Scribe [[harpsichord]], or machine for writing with keys"). It was an advanced machine that let the user see the writing as it was typed. *In 1861, Father Francisco João de Azevedo, a Brazilian priest, made his own typewriter with basic materials and tools, such as wood and knives. In that same year the Brazilian emperor [[Pedro II of Brazil|D. Pedro II]], presented a gold medal to Father Azevedo for this invention. Many Brazilian people as well as the Brazilian federal government recognize Fr. Azevedo as the inventor of the typewriter, a claim that has been the subject of some controversy.{{Citation needed|date=July 2012}} *In 1865, John Pratt, of [[Centre, Alabama]] (US), built a machine called the ''Pterotype'' which appeared in an 1867 ''[[Scientific American]]'' article.<ref>{{Cite news | date = 1867-07-06 | title = Type Writing Machine. | periodical = [[Scientific American]] | series = New | place = New York | volume = 17 | issue = 1 | page = 3 | url = http://cdl.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/moa/pageviewer?frames=1&coll=moa&view=50&root=%2Fmoa%2Fscia%2Fscia1017%2F&tif=00011.TIF&cite=http%3A%2F%2Fcdl.library.cornell.edu%2Fcgi-bin%2Fmoa%2Fmoa-cgi%3Fnotisid%3DABF2204-1017-3 | accessdate = 2009-01-14 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. --> }}</ref> and inspired other inventors. *Between 1864 and 1867 {{Interlanguage link multi|Peter Mitterhofer|de}}, a carpenter from [[South Tyrol]] (then part of [[Austrian Empire|Austria]]) developed several models and a fully functioning prototype typewriter in 1867.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wN4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA751|author=Hearst Magazines|title=Popular Mechanics|date=May 1929|page=751|publisher=Hearst Magazines}}</ref> *1895 saw brief production of the [[Ford Typewriter|Ford typewriter]], which featured the first typewriter with [[aluminum]] construction<ref>{{cite journal|date=June 1896|title=Trade Notes|journal=The Aluminum World|location=New York|volume=11|issue=9|page=183|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-QxaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA183}}</ref> and forward-thrust key movement.
====Hansen Writing Ball==== {{main|Hansen Writing Ball}} [[File:Writing ball keyboard 3.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Hansen Writing Ball]] was the first typewriter manufactured commercially (1870)]]
In 1865, Rev. [[Rasmus Malling-Hansen]] of [[Denmark]] invented the [[Hansen Writing Ball]], which went into commercial production in 1870 and was the first commercially sold typewriter. It was a success in Europe and was reported as being used in offices in London as late as 1909.<ref name=Mares>{{cite book|last=Mares|first=G. C.|title=The History of the Typewriter|year=1909|location=London|page=230}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Early Office Museum|url=http://www.officemuseum.com/typewriters.htm|accessdate=1 December 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102201621/http://www.officemuseum.com/typewriters.htm|archivedate=2 January 2014|df=}}</ref> Malling-Hansen used a [[solenoid]] escapement to return the carriage on some of his models which makes him a candidate for the title of inventor of the first "electric" typewriter.
According to the book ''Hvem er skrivekuglens opfinder?'' (English: ''Who is the inventor of the Writing Ball?''), written by Malling-Hansen's daughter, Johanne Agerskov, in 1865, Malling-Hansen made a porcelain model of the keyboard of his writing ball and experimented with different placements of the letters to achieve the fastest writing speed. Malling-Hansen placed the letters on short pistons that went directly through the ball and down to the paper. This, together with the placement of the letters so that the fastest writing fingers struck the most frequently used letters, made the Hansen Writing Ball the first typewriter to produce text substantially faster than a person could write by hand.
The Hansen Writing Ball was produced with only upper-case characters.
